title: Understanding Endometrial Cancer
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.text: Understanding the most common type of uterine cancer

content.value: Endometrial cancer starts in the lining of the uterus (the endometrium). It is one of the most common gynaecological cancers and is often diagnosed at an early stage because it frequently causes abnormal uterine bleeding, particularly after menopause.

items: Most common in postmenopausal women
Often detected early due to abnormal bleeding
Earlier diagnosis is associated with better treatment outcomes
Risk factors include obesity, hormone therapy, and increasing age

content.value: Abnormal uterine bleeding — including bleeding after menopause, between periods, or changes in menstrual patterns — should be checked. Early assessment is important, as earlier-stage diagnosis is linked with better outcomes.
Endometrial cancer develops when cells in the uterine lining grow abnormally. Understanding this process helps guide early detection and treatment.

items.title: Type 1 Endometrial Cancer
items.description: The most common type. Often linked to excess estrogen exposure and typically slower growing.

items.title: Type 2 Endometrial Cancer
items.description: Less common and tends to behave more aggressively. It is not usually linked to estrogen and is more likely to spread.

items.title: Endometrial Hyperplasia
items.description: Some women develop endometrial hyperplasia, where the lining becomes thickened due to abnormal cell growth. Treatment can reduce the risk of progression to cancer.

content.title: Did You Know?
content.value: Detecting and treating endometrial hyperplasia early can lower the chance of it developing into endometrial cancer.
These factors increase risk but do not mean you will develop endometrial cancer:

items: Increasing age, especially after menopause
Long-term exposure to oestrogen without progesterone
Obesity
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
Early first period or late menopause
Having no full-term pregnancies
Oestrogen-only hormone replacement therapy
Tamoxifen use
Family history, particularly Lynch syndrome

content.title: Protective Factors
content.description: Pregnancy, use of combined hormonal contraceptives, and maintaining a healthy body weight are associated with a lower risk.

content.value: Endometrial cancer often shows early warning signs. The most common is abnormal vaginal bleeding.

items: Unusual bleeding or spotting between periods or after menopause
Long, heavy, or frequent bleeding (especially in women over 40)
Thin white or clear vaginal discharge (postmenopausal women)
Lower abdominal or pelvic pain
A lump or mass in the lower abdomen
Difficulty or pain while urinating
Pain during sexual intercourse
Unexplained weight loss

content.title: Important
content.description: If you experience any of these symptoms, it's important to seek medical evaluation.

content.value: If endometrial cancer is suspected, several steps may be taken.

steps: Review of medical and family history
Transvaginal ultrasound to assess the womb lining
Endometrial biopsy to sample the uterine lining
Dilation and curettage (D&C) if more tissue is needed for diagnosis

content.value: Cervical screening tests are not designed to detect endometrial cancer, but may occasionally identify abnormal cells.

content.title: If cancer is confirmed
content.description: If cancer is confirmed, your doctor will determine the stage, which indicates how far the cancer has spread, and the grade, which describes how abnormal the cancer cells look under a microscope. These factors help guide treatment decisions.

content.value: Treatment depends on the cancer stage, type, and your overall health.

content.text: A gynaecological oncology team may recommend:

items.title: Surgery
items.description: Often the main treatment. This usually involves removal of the uterus, ovaries, and fallopian tubes. Lymph nodes may also be assessed.

items.title: Radiotherapy
items.description: High-energy treatment used after surgery or, in some cases, as the main treatment..

items.title: Chemotherapy
items.description: Anti-cancer medicines that destroy or slow cancer growth, often used in higher-stage disease.

items.title: Hormone Therapy
items.description: May be used in selected cases where the cancer is hormone-sensitive.

items.title: Combination Treatment
items.description: Some people receive a combination of treatments depending on their diagnosis.

content.title: Key Point
content.description: Treatment plans are personalised based on the cancer stage, type, and your overall health.

content.value: While not all cases can be prevented, some steps may reduce risk and support early diagnosis.

content.title: Why Prevention Matters
content.description: Earlier diagnosis is associated with better treatment outcomes. Awareness of symptoms and risk factors is important.

items.text: Using combined hormonal contraceptives (which are associated with lower risk)
Managing PCOS and metabolic health with medical advice
Considering genetic testing if you have a strong family history or Lynch syndrome
Using combined (estrogen + progesterone) HRT if hormone therapy is needed

items: Seek medical advice for abnormal uterine bleeding
Postmenopausal bleeding should always be checked
There is no routine screening programme for endometrial cancer
Awareness of abnormal bleeding is crucial
Managing lifestyle factors may help reduce risk

content.title: Key Takeway
content.description: Understanding risk factors and seeking prompt medical advice for symptoms can support earlier diagnosis.

content.title: What You Should Know
content.description: Endometrial cancer is often diagnosed early because it commonly causes noticeable symptoms, especially postmenopausal bleeding. Earlier diagnosis is linked with better treatment outcomes, and managing lifestyle factors such as body weight is associated with lower risk.

items.text: Postmenopausal bleeding should always be checked
Earlier diagnosis is associated with more effective treatment
Maintaining a healthy weight may help reduce risk
Managing PCOS and hormonal health with medical advice is important
Seek medical review if you have symptoms or risk factors

content.title: Final Message
content.description: Staying aware of warning signs and seeking medical advice promptly if symptoms occur can make an important difference to your health.
